texts.definition: A phase where the focus is upon increase the amount of a game world on controls.
markups: <style="Definition">A phase where the focus is upon increase the amount of a game world on controls.</style>

In some games players can gain control of parts of the game worlds. Those games where a part of game instances typically focus upon this activity are said to have <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> phases.
Note: The pattern dealing with additional content to games is the similarly named Expansions.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> phases in their gameplay arcs following initial exploration. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> has this to a lesser extent in the form of nations with the idea group "Quest for the New World" being able to explore and colonize areas of the world without existing organized settlements.

Matches in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style> typically start directly with <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> phases since players are likely to know the maps being played already.

While there are some basic requirements of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> in terms of size for <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> to be possible, more specific patterns control if and when it occurs in gameplay instances. Having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> can be seen as one definition of the pattern, and this can be enabled either by occupation of <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> or by <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="entrenching-gameplay">Entrenching Gameplay</link></style> or the growth of <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style> stemming from these can be the most direct indication that one is in <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> phases of a game instance. Given players <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals can make moving in <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> phases literal commandments to them.

The possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> and the rate at which it is possible can be controlled rather easily in game designs. This through limiting <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> possibilities until access to the right <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technologies">Technologies</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> have been achieved. By introducing costs related to <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style>, it may also be required that players have achieved sufficiently good <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style>. When the gameplay making up <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> focuses on <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or the creation of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> the end of the phase can be described as a
<style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shift</link></style> and modified by the specifics of how such a shift occurs.

The location of these in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> - as well as the size and terrain in these - greatly affect the directions <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> will take and how long this phase can continue in games. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style> can also affect how long players wish to stay in the phase if they can choose.

Expansion is typically design to be a gameplay phase occurring after Game World Exploration. This can be followed by Exploitation and then optionally Extermination. The use of all four of these X phases define 4X games.

Due to that it often makes use of <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Expansion</style> is likely to give rise to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> in a game. It is often part of the <style="Link"><link="middlegame">Middlegame</link></style> of a game when <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style> are not known at the beginning of gameplay, otherwise it is likely part of the <style="Link"><link="startgame">Startgame</link></style> (as is the case in most game instances in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft</link></style> games).
